prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The sensitivity is based on the continuum. Band 6 is chosen because it has better phase stability than Band 7, it provides the necessary spatial resolution and has shown to provide good constraints on the dust distribution.
To quantify the required sensitivity and resolvability of hole sizes, the 230 GHz flux is taken from the literature or extrapolated from the 345 GHz flux. Using a generic model of a transitional disk continuum distribution, we derived the required S/N to image and resolve the dust holes (see Figure 2). According to this model, most of the flux originates from the inner 120 AU of the disk. Spreading the total flux over <120 AU (<0.92" 4x4=16 beams), and requiring a S/N of at least 3sigma per beam, the total flux divided by number of beams has to be at least 48, requiring a total flux of at least 2 mJy for 0.05 mJy/bm noise, which is the rms level of 6 minute integrations.
The targets are grouped per star forming region for each Science Goal, due to the 10 degree distance restriction. Since each group contains targets of high and low 230 GHz flux, the sensitivity requirement is set to the minimum of 0.05 mJy/bm, so that even the faintest targets can be imaged.

The correlator is set to four spectral windows of 1875 MHz, to obtain the highest continuum sensitivity of the 7.5 GHz bandwidth (0.05 mJy/bm/6 minutes). One baseband is centered on the 12CO 2-1 line, for potential detection of this line. The other basebands are not centered on specific lines, but lines may be picked up serendipitously. Spectral averaging has been set to lower the data rate below the 12 Mb/s limit.

The extended configuration C36-5 is chosen providing 0.23''(15--30 AU radius) resolution. Since the dust hole radii are expected to be at least 25 AU, this resolution is sufficient to resolve the hole for each target.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The evolutionary phase from protoplanetary disks into planetary systems is formed by the transitional disks with large inner holes. For only ~20 of these disks the hole size has been confirmed by resolved submillimeter imaging, which makes it difficult to get good statistics on the hole size distribution. At the same time, the statistics on exoplanets at larger orbital radii are getting better through high-contrast AO imaging techniques, radial velocity observations and the Kepler mission. For a better understanding of the role of giant planets in disk evolution, a large unbiased sample of transitional disks with measured cavity sizes is essential. We propose here to use 4.25 hours of ALMA Band 6 continuum observations to survey a sample of 21 candidate giant planet host disks selected from complete infrared Spitzer surveys. With ALMA Cycle 2, dust holes down to 15 AU radius can be resolved within <8 minutes per target. The sample would more than double the existing sample of transitional disks with measured cavity radii. The complete sample will help to address statistical questions with exoplanetary studies and can be used for future high resolution gas studies with ALMA.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: European Space Astronomy Centre (ESAC), European Space Agency
Kavli Institute for Astronomy and Astrophysics, Peking University
